profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-12-05T13:45-0500

did.unittitle: Bill Bahlman Papers
did.abstract: William (Bill) Bahlman is an activist and journalist, working since the 1970's to fight for access to medications for all people with HIV and AIDS and to document this fight through photography and videography. He is currently associate producer for a weekly news program of GLBTQ interest and serves on AIDS research advisory boards, while living with HIV since the 1980's. This collection includes copies of flyers Mr. Bahlman created for AIDS advocacy campaigns, AIDS-related newspaper articles, and selected testimony before Presidential and Congressional Commissions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Bill Bahlman Papers (glbtq.1998.01). GLBTQ Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: William (Bill) Bahlman is a long-term activist and journalist. A member of the Gay Activists Alliance in the 1970s, Bill Bahlman was a co-founder of both the Lavender Hill Mob and ACT UP New York. He served on the Issues Committee of ACT UP which tirelessly studied every aspect of drug development and of the government’s response to HIV/AIDS. Mr. Bahlman served on countless community, government and industry advisory boards fighting for expanded access and faster development of life saving drugs. He was news director and co-anchor of “Out in the 80’s / 90’s” and is currently associate producer of Gay USA, a weekly hour of news, analysis and interviews. Bill Bahlman is also an accomplished photographer and videographer. His work appears in two AIDS documentary films; “Testing the Limits” and the 2012 Oscar nominated film by director David France “How to Survive a Plague;” he appears in France’s film as a community reporter and as a treatment advocate from ACT UP New York. Mr. Bahlman was diagnosed as HIV-positive in 1989.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Bill Bahlman Papers are almost totally AIDS related. They include early flyers from the Lavender Hill Mob and from ACT UP, New York City. There are copies of testimony before the Presidential Commission on AIDS (1987-88) and of Congressional testimony. There are some photocopies of AIDS related newspaper articles. The range of materials includes copies of flyers, newspaper articles, statements and testimony before Senate and Congressional committees.
